commentBody:
A very liberal (not objective) article. The author weaves selectively through data.

He does ask why the Lenin shipyards have been almost vanquished by the Civic Platform (so EU's shipyards could continue to thrive).

The Civic Platform leadership placed 75% of the military at the German border. To defend Germany against a Russian invasion while leaving Poland's east exposed?

replies.commentBody: Waldek you have very limited knowledge on current situation in Poland, which in fact is shifting toward authoritarism, Catholic fundamentalism and anty-west (UE) sentiment. The true is that current polish government is a group of people featured with fatal mix of post soviet mentality and rural pre Soboral Catholicism. Sad but true.

Former "Lenin" Shipyard was sold, along with many government-based companies, because it was making loss. It drained from Treasury donations, and still, it was artificial prolonging life.

But during fiscal year 2015 shipyards in Gdańsk (old shipyard was parted) made profit higher than ever. Emploeyees get paid more than before (true, there are fewer of them). Why? Because shipyards concentrated on building luxury yachts and parts for windmills powerplants. For Polish industry it was nearly impossible to get to the same level in building ships like in Western Europe or Asia (and it was too costly).

In the end I will add - I too believe that author wasn't presenting facts as best as James Traub could.

And... sorry for bad english ;)

"He does ask why the Lenin shipyards have been almost vanquished by the Civic Platform (so EU's shipyards could continue to thrive). "
Speculation, there were many discussions about what to do about the shipyards as they were financially insolvent for a long time due to extreme inefficiencies

"The Civic Platform leadership placed 75% of the military at the German border. To defend Germany against a Russian invasion while leaving Poland's east exposed?"
No major base was ever built in the east. I grew up there. The reason 75% of military is closer to western border was because that's where the bases and support infrastructure was built for 45 years after WW2. Building even a single base is a significant undertaking so reforming military was a better choice during Russian post-Soviet era.
